ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Your experience with the Clinic really depends on your team members and the project you're assigned to. I felt that my team did not work well together and I was skeptical of the general conceptual framework of my project, so it was not a great experience for me.
The value of this course is in the project-based learning with a client; I was not personally interested in the subject matter covered by the lectures
student experience and satisfaction with the course depends on which project you're assigned to for the semester

The readings were not relevant to all projects. Readings were generally US-focused, but several teams (including my own) had projects with an international focus or that did not involve environmental law per se.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The real-world application gave our work more weight than most school projects.
Working directly with a client on a project very relevant to my studies at F&ES.
The class offers "real-world" experience in addition to following the format of a class. I enjoyed being exposed to client-based work.
working on the client project.
The client project options were fantastic
Working on deliverables for a respected client and being able to add that experience to my CV.
Working directly with clients is great, and working with teams offers a great chance to see issues from the perspectives of other disciplines.

I thought the guest lectures went really well. It was great to have lectures about how environmental policy is made from professionals actually doing it out in the field. I also thought that having one class to compare and contrast project types and problems was useful, although given how different the project topics and scopes are, I don't know that we would need to have more than one.
Josh and Dave were very helpful and went out of their way to answer any questions or concerns. This class was amazing!
Working on a project for a client is so important for the "real-world" aspect of the work. You're informing decisions that are being made real-time. You learn so much more this way.
Excellent opportunity to work in a group and with a client. Allows students to apply useful skills and create a real work product.
I had a great project! Whether or not this course is valuable depends entirely on your project and what you end up making of it.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The classes weren't always very interesting or relevant to the work I was doing. Made it difficult to attend them.
I think there should be some kind of team exercise where you talk about your individual work styles and expectations, so that those things are clear from the beginning.
lecture topics sometimes not interesting or relevant. need a more diverse set of speakers. most came from nrdc. need a more diverse perspective on environmental issues.

This may be beyond the control of the instructors, but, as with any class, some of the guest lecturers were hit or miss. It might also have been helpful to transfer the law overview part of the course into a short reading, so students would have more time to ask questions and take advantage of the expertise of the instructors during that section's class time.
scheduling for group meetings and expectations need to be defined by the group well and quickly and work needs to get started as soon as possible.
Maybe some more accountability for mid-term deliverables along the way.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in development economics among agrarian communities in the tropics, so our project fits right in line with my career path.
Provides real client engagement experience in school, has been by far more concrete course so far

Because the main portion of this class was working directly with a client, this course was important for my career development (as it can count as a consultancy and helped me gain contacts in the field.)
very valuable hands on experience and good experience working with a client
I want to use this course as a capstone, and taking it this year would enable me to skip lectures for it in my final year.
This course was the first time that I had worked with a client and I learned very important skills for my career.

I was working on a project that was researching CA law on fisheries management, and when I graduate I want to work for the CA department of fish and wildlife. This experience was very important for me.

Very useful application of the skills I learn in the classroom. I get to interact with a real client and develop a relevant work product. This deliverable commonly addresses issues that I'm currently studying.
Capstone! The project I worked on for this course combined a lot of the elements that I have been studying during my time here.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above.
Because of the specific opportunity available to work with an individual client on a project that interests me greatly.
Capstone.
To get consulting experience
This course was important for my career development (as it can count as a consultancy and helped me gain contacts in the field.)
I wanted to gain experience working on a client-based project.
wanted more practical experience and final deliverable that could be added to resume
I wanted to do a very specific project and get a handle on the course that I might take again as a capstone.
Excited to have the chance to work on real-world projects, and to get some information and experience in managing client relationships remotely.
To gain practical experience with environmental policy.
I wanted to expose myself to new projects and to build a network outside of the Yale community.
I wanted to work on an applied project that would have a product useful to an organization.
for the project I worked on.
To get more applied experience.
To apply the theories and frameworks I'd been learning about in practice.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes, but it was mostly self-learning from research as opposed to knowledge / skills I gained from the instructors / lectures.
Yes.
Yes
Yes. I learned so much about the topic that I was working on. I also gained a lot of insight into client-consultant interactions that will be helpful in my career going forward.
learned a lot from researching our topic for our project
Yes
Mostly.

The class was very valuable, though not in all the ways I expected. My client's focus ended up drawing on my skills less than their initial proposal made out, so at first I struggled with feeling a bit extraneous to the project. That being said, I learned a lot about our focus area, and picked up some new research experience, which was also helpful.
How to read and understand law and legislation.
Yes.

Yes. For students thinking in work as consultants, the experience in very valuable. It is a "safe" environment to get exposed to the consultants/independent worker world, which is an incredible experience to learn before graduation.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to work with others, to share the work load, and improve upon one another's products.

Advantages were that we could cover more ground on our research, disadvantages were that finding scheduled time that worked, and sticking with our timeline was difficult. Some people were more motivated than others to complete the deliverables.
Sometimes hard to properly coordinate/delegate teamwork and jointly manage client expectations
The same as all group work- nice to share ideas and work with a team, but often difficult to coordinate working schedules.
I found it difficult to coordinate to meet.
we were able to broaden our scope in our research because we had multiple people working on the same topic. hard to find a time to have weekly meetings with everyone's busy schedules.

My group was actually just a two person team, and we worked very well together. The only disadvantage I would say was logistics (sometimes one person was traveling or had technical problems and the other had to account for that in his/her work).

Could be tough to coordinate schedules, and I wished we'd done a better job of taking advantage of each other's expertise. But working on a team was really valuable - apart from learning more about the topic we were working on, I learned a lot by simply watching different approaches to organizing work and interacting with our clients.

Advantages - being able to split up the workload, having people with different backgrounds and experience helped to answer each others' questions. Disadvantages - so many hours spent emailing, waiting for other people to finish their part.
I was very lucky to be in such an incredible group.
It was great to collaborate with other students, given that they had other experiences and expertise.
My group was all interested in the subject and everyone worked really hard on our project. I loved everyone in the group!
Collaboration creates a more powerful work product. Organization and delegation are a challenge, but can be overcome with committed, diligent group members. I had a great experience with my group.
Fortunately, my group was an excellent team. The discussions, difference of views, personal abilities and capabilities were a perfect mix. Great "human quality" of the team.
I had a group with one person I knew very well and one I did not know, which had its advantages and disadvantages. Overall, leadership is tricky in groups.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Pick your project carefully.
Pick a client project you are excited about!
Talk to people who are interested in the same projects before they are assigned.
Don't overstate level of commitment if only can deliver so many hours to client
It really depends on the project you're working on, but this can be a great course.
If you want to put what you have learned in the classroom to the test through interacting with a client on a real-world issue--take this course! I would recommend this course to anyone.

research the project before signing on to work on it for the entire semester. be in very open communication with your project supervisor and client. be flexible and realistic about deadlines and final deliverables.
Take this class for sure.
Make sure you get a project you are really interested in.

I would suggest shopping this class early in your career, so you have the chance to pick and work on a project that really speaks to and interests you, and so you can continue it, if you enjoy working on it.
Choose a topic you are interested in, but also try to set up a group with people that you know you want to work with and who will pull their weight!
Every FES student should take this course before graduating. It teaches invaluable life and career skills.
keep up with the hours very week. Create weekly deadlines for yourself and keep track of your work.

The workload in this course is very heavy, but the clinic is one of the most useful courses offered at FES. You learn critical skills that are not necessarily offered in other courses, including client interaction, group collaboration, legal writing/research, etc. The clinic also allows you to create a real work product at the end of the semester, which can greatly enhance your resume. Be sure to check in regularly with your client to get feedback pertaining to your deliverable, and be clear about team responsibilities early on.
Lisa was late to nearly every meeting we scheduled. This was incredibly disappointing for us.
- Take it only with a project that you are 100% sure that you want to be part of. - If you can, try to work with a group willing to discuss and share different views of the project.
Choose your project carefully and try to collect your group members beforehand to ensure that you are working with people you trust.
